abstract: American Cancer Society researchers report significant rise in number of women under age 26 who have been diagnosed with early-stage cervical cancer; contend pattern is mostly likely a positive effect of Affordable Care Act, which has allowed dependents to stay on parental health insurance plans until age 26.
lead_paragraph: Researchers say there has been a substantial increase in women under the age of 26 who have received a diagnosis of early-stage cervical cancer since the health law came into effect in 2010.

headline.main: Rise in Early Cervical Cancer Detection Is Linked to Affordable Care Act
headline.print_headline: Rise in Early Cancer Detection in Young Women Is Linked to Affordable Care Act

snippet: Researchers say there has been a substantial increase in women under the age of 26 who have received a diagnosis of early-stage cervical cancer since the health law came into effect in 2010.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject
